section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build math background, engage children with song, and introduce vocabulary (mitten, add).
Begin Story Time by asking, What is one animal that goes into the mitten?
Read for enjoyment with a focus on operations.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Understand that adding or taking away one from a small group of objects changes the total quantity by one; Use fingers, objects, or drawings to show a verbal word problem adding to or subtracting from a set of up to 5 objects.
Use the last number counted to tell “how many” are in a set (Cardinality).
Identify and verbalize needs.
Speak clearly enough to be understood.
Investigate, describe, and talk about objects that can be seen in the sky; Describe what happens when the earth or the sky changes.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Have children use counters to represent animals as they enter and leave the “mitten.”
Guide children to add and take away one from a given number and understand that the total changes by one.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What is the weather in this story?
What animal can you pretend to be?
Can you add one more block to your pattern? How many are there now?
Can you write about an animal playing in the snow?
What materials can you use to make a mitten?
Trace the word snow. What letter does it start with?
Build a shelter that would protect animals from the cold.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder talk about your needs and introduce vocabulary (communicate).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to The Mitten.
Read closely to notice how characters express their needs and review operations.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Understand that adding or taking away one from a small group of objects changes the total quantity by one; Use fingers, objects, or drawings to show a verbal word problem adding to or subtracting from a set of up to 5 objects.
Use the last number counted to tell “how many” are in a set (Cardinality).
Identify and verbalize needs; Share ideas and feelings.
Speak clearly enough to be understood.

section-block.tg_skills-focus_body: Economics: Show understanding that people have basic needs, e.g., food, clothing, and shelter.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Give partners each a certain number of Connecting Cubes.
Ask for a different number of cubes, and guide partners to verbalize need for one more or less cube to meet the new number.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How do the characters in this book show what they need?
Act like you are hungry! How can you show someone in the kitchen that you need food?
Take away one block from the pattern. How did the number of blocks change?
Write a story about a character who needs something.
Draw two people communicating. What are they saying?
What sound do you hear at the beginning of communicate? Can you make that letter?
Work with a partner to build something that would help keep you warm on a snowy day.

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. The Mitten by Jim Aylesworth, illustrated by Barbara McClintock. Text copyright © 2009 by Jim Aylesworth. Illustrations copyright © 2009 by Barbara McClintock. Published by Scholastic Inc. Clifford the Big Red DogTM illustration copyright © The Norman Bridwell Trust.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to practice graphing, sort children by attribute, and introduce vocabulary (total, graph).
Begin Story Time by revisiting The Mitten and asking the guiding question, Why do the animals go in the mitten?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension and to review classification.
Check understanding. Differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use the last number counted to tell “how many” are in a set (Cardinality).
Describe and sort objects by similarities and differences; Collect, organize, and present data graphically.
Identify and verbalize needs.
Speak clearly enough to be understood.
Investigate, describe, and talk about objects that can be seen in the sky; Describe what happens when the earth or the sky changes.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Have children sort their own handwear into two groups: mittens and gloves.
Guide children to create a bar graph using sticky notes and compare totals of mittens and gloves.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How does the character in this book feel about the weather?
Pretend that you are outside in the cold snow. How can you warm up?
How can you sort these blocks?
Would you rather wear mittens or gloves? Write about why.
Can you draw a glove? Why did you use those colors?
What letter do you see more than once in the word mitten?
Sometimes we lose our gloves or mittens. Build a lost and found box where we could put anything we find that isn’t ours.

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. The Mitten by Jim Aylesworth, illustrated by Barbara McClintock. Text copyright © 2009 by Jim Aylesworth. Illustrations copyright © 2009 by Barbara McClintock. Published by Scholastic Inc.

tg_materials-caption.tg_materials-caption_book-title-Ital: Big Chart of Big Ideas: What’s the Weather?

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to talk about weather, engage children with a game, and introduce vocabulary (snowy, windy).
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts What’s the Weather? and The Mitten.
Read closely to connect to this week’s guiding question, How can weather affect us?
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use the last number counted to tell “how many” are in a set (Cardinality).
Describe and sort objects by similarities and differences; Collect, organize, and present data graphically.
Identify and verbalize needs.
Speak clearly enough to be understood.

section-block.tg_skills-focus_body: Economics: Show understanding that people have basic needs, e.g., food, clothing, and shelter.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Investigate, describe, and talk about objects that can be seen in the sky; Describe what happens when the earth or the sky changes.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Have children sort activity cards by the type of weather they show.
Guide children to create a bar graph using the activity cards and compare totals of each weather type.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What are the people wearing in this story? Does it give you a hint about the weather?
Pretend it is raining. What would be the best thing to wear?
Can you sort these blocks by color? Which group is biggest?
What weather do you think would be best to have all the time? Write a story about that.
Create a snowy field. What materials are best to use?
Trace the word weather. What letter does it end with?
Build a shelter for snowy weather. Now build a shelter for sunny weather. Let’s compare them!

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. The Mitten by Jim Aylesworth, illustrated by Barbara McClintock. Text copyright © 2009 by Jim Aylesworth. Illustrations copyright © 2009 by Barbara McClintock. Published by Scholastic Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to connect to science, engage children with a game, and introduce vocabulary (cozy, sound asleep).
Start Story Time by revisiting the book and asking, How does the cold weather affect the boy or the animals?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and a focus on operations.
Check understanding. Differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Understand that adding or taking away one from a small group of objects changes the total quantity by one; Use fingers, objects, or drawings to show a verbal word problem adding to or subtracting from a set of up to 5 objects.
Use the last number counted to tell “how many” are in a set (Cardinality).
Describe and sort objects by similarities and differences.
Identify and verbalize needs.
Speak clearly enough to be understood.
Investigate, describe, and talk about objects that can be seen in the sky.
Write for different purposes.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: What do you do to stay warm when it’s cold?
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s writing to display next week.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Imagine you are the character in this book. What type of weather would be your favorite?
Imagine you are in a country where it is snowy all the time. What will you wear?
Can you create a pattern that looks like a snowflake?
Write a story about a cozy place.
Use clay to make an animal that is sound asleep.
Create a name for a new type of weather. What letter does it start with?
Build a shelter that will protect animals from a totally new type of weather. What will your shelter need to have? What materials will you use?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. The Mitten by Jim Aylesworth, illustrated by Barbara McClintock. Text copyright © 2009 by Jim Aylesworth. Illustrations copyright © 2009 by Barbara McClintock. Published by Scholastic Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use concrete objects, create pictorial models, and share a verbal word problem for adding up to 5 objects.
Use concrete models or make a verbal word problem for subtracting 0–5 objects from a set.
Count up to 10 items and demonstrate that the last count indicates how many items were counted.
Identify and verbalize needs.
Speech is understood by both the teacher and other adults in the school.
Identify, observe, and discuss objects in the sky.
Observe and describe what happens during changes in the earth and sky.
Use concrete objects, create pictorial models, and share a verbal word problem for adding up to 5 objects.
Use concrete models or make a verbal word problem for subtracting 0–5 objects from a set.
Count up to 10 items and demonstrate that the last count indicates how many items were counted.
Identify and verbalize needs.
Show competence initiating social interactions.
Speech is understood by both the teacher and other adults in the school.
Demonstrate that all people need food, clothing, and shelter.
Count up to 10 items and demonstrate that the last count indicates how many items were counted.
Sort objects that are the same and different into groups.
Collect data and organize it in a graphic representation.
Identify and verbalize needs.
Speech is understood by both the teacher and other adults in the school.
Identify, observe, and discuss objects in the sky.
Observe and describe what happens during changes in the earth and sky.
Count up to 10 items and demonstrate that the last count indicates how many items were counted.
Sort objects that are the same and different into groups.
Collect data and organize it in a graphic representation.
Identify and verbalize needs.
Speech is understood by both the teacher and other adults in the school.
Demonstrate that all people need food, clothing, and shelter.
Identify, observe, and discuss objects in the sky.
Observe and describe what happens during changes in the earth and sky.
Use concrete objects, create pictorial models, and share a verbal word problem for adding up to 5 objects.
Use concrete models or make a verbal word problem for subtracting 0–5 objects from a set.
Count up to 10 items and demonstrate that the last count indicates how many items were counted.
Sort objects that are the same and different into groups.
Identify and verbalize needs.
Speech is understood by both the teacher and other adults in the school.
Identify, observe, and discuss objects in the sky.
Independently write to communicate ideas.
